content: More U.S. merchandise trade is carried by oceangoing vessels than by airplanes, trucks, freight trains, and pipelines combined. Harbor maintenance plays a critical role in facilitating U.S. foreign trade and reducing trade costs between different regions. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is responsible for maintaining federal waterways and harbor channels. The U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is responsible for maintaining federal waterways and harbor channels, which are crucial for facilitating U.S. foreign trade. Congress relies on the Water Resources Development Act to revisit harbor maintenance policy, as decisions on harbor maintenance now have a greater impact on the U.S. economy due to the increase in merchandise trade accounting for 25% of GDP. The cost of harbor maintenance is supported by a harbor maintenance tax (HMT) on imported and domestic waterborne cargo and cruise passengers, generating revenue for the harbor maintenance trust fund (HMTF) used by the Corps for dredging channels and maintaining jetties and breakwaters. The harbor maintenance tax (HMT) on imported waterborne cargo funds the harbor maintenance trust fund (HMTF) for dredging channels, maintaining jetties, and operating locks. HMT revenue is scored as federal receipts, and a surplus reduces the federal budget deficit. About half of the HMT collected annually is spent on harbor maintenance. The Harbor Maintenance Tax (HMT) surplus reduces the federal budget deficit. Over half of the HMT collected annually is used for harbor maintenance. The trust fund balance was $8.5 billion in July 2013. The Corps expects $2.05 billion income in FY2014 from HMT and interest. The Administration's budget requests $923 million for harbor maintenance. Bills in the 113th Congress aim to increase annual funding. The budget requests $923 million for harbor maintenance. Bills in the 113th Congress aim to double annual spending on harbor maintenance, with H.R. 3080 proposing to increase HMTF expenditures every year. This could potentially reduce funding for other activities. Congress established the Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) in 1986 to allocate 80% of the HMT collected for harbor maintenance. Increasing HMTF spending may reduce funding for other Corps activities, requiring reallocation within the federal budget. The Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) was established by Congress in 1986 to allocate funds for harbor maintenance. The funds are designated for commercial navigation operations and maintenance costs of harbors and inland harbors in the United States. Harbors are defined as capable of transporting commercial cargo by vessels, while inland harbors are primarily used for accommodating commercial vessels and handling waterborne cargoes. The Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) was established in 1986 to allocate funds for harbor maintenance. Inland harbors are defined as primarily used for commercial vessels and waterborne cargoes, while coastal or Great Lakes harbors only need to be capable of handling cargo. Commercial cargo includes passengers but excludes fresh-caught fish, and ferries are not considered commercial vessels. These definitions have remained unchanged since 1986, and there was no rulemaking to implement the harbor maintenance provisions in WRDA 1986. The Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) was established in 1986 to allocate funds for harbor maintenance. The Corps interprets "commercial navigation" as any project authorized by Congress with commercial navigation as an authorized purpose. Most harbor projects are authorized as "single-purpose" commercial navigation projects, with all O&M costs payable from the HMTF. The Harbor Maintenance Trust Fund (HMTF) covers O&M costs for "single-purpose" commercial navigation projects. "Multi-purpose" projects only allow recovery of costs related to commercial navigation.
